objectives.description: Recognize various forms of charitable giving including monetary donations, volunteering, in-kind gifts, and planned giving.
Learn how charitable giving can be incorporated into comprehensive financial planning at any income level.
Discover the personal and societal benefits that come from giving back to your community.
Consider non-monetary ways to contribute to your community regardless of your financial situation.

terms.definition: Direct financial contributions made to a charitable organization to support their mission.
terms.example: One-time gifts, recurring donations, matching gifts through employers, crowdfunding contributions

terms.definition: Contributions of goods or services rather than money, often equally valuable to organizations.
terms.example: Clothing, food, professional services pro bono, technology equipment, blood donation

terms.definition: Donating time or skills to support causes without receiving financial compensation.
terms.example: Direct impact, skill development, networking, mental health benefits, career exploration

terms.definition: Charitable contributions arranged through long-term financial or estate planning.
terms.example: Bequests in wills, charitable trusts, endowments, life insurance designations

scenario.name: Maria: The Power of Volunteering in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Maria, a college student with limited financial resources, volunteers 5 hours each week at a local food bank.
Although she can't make substantial monetary donations, her consistent time commitment helps the organization serve hundreds of meals each month.
Within six months, she was given more responsibility and now coordinates other volunteers during her shifts. She also gained experience that helped her secure an internship in nonprofit management.

scenario.name: James: Skills-Based Giving in {{STATE_NAME}}
